questions.text: A group of people became ill with nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal cramps, and diarrhea after eating undercooked hamburgers in a local party. Two of them were diagnosed as hemolytic-uremic syndrome caused by EHEC O157:H7 . The O157 refers to which bacterial structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Choose the correct bacterial gene transfer method as shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Image shown here is direct uptake of naked DNA from environment – Transformation.

questions.text: In a culture media, a particular period the bacteria lost its morphology and become involutional forms. This change is seen in which of the following phase of bacterial growth curve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bacterial growth curve, In decline phase, involutional forms are occur due to lack of nutrition and accumulation of toxic metabolites.
It is filamentous / coccoid form of bacteria

questions.text: Name the quality control agent used to sterilize the item shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paraffin wax is sterilized by using Hot air oven – dry heat method. 
QCA for this method is Bacillus atropheus sub spp niger.

questions.text: As per Spaulding classification, image shown here belongs to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Image shown here is cardiac catheter.
Asper Spaulding classification it belongs to Critical.

questions.text: E.coli form pus specimen grown in a medium as shown in the image. This medium belongs to all the following types of media except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

MacConkey agar is a solid, selective, differential and indicator medium.

questions.text: In a metropolitan city, a sudden out break of black death happened. Investigation team found; it is a bacterial disease transmitted from rats to human via rat flea bite. They strongly suspect that this disease is a bio-war. As per categorization of Bioterrorism agents, this disease-causing agent classified under which category?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The disease-causing agent is Yersinia pestis.
Outbreak is plague
Plague came under Category A bioterrorism agent.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with the complaints of burning mituration and dysuria. Urine sent for culture. E. coli grown in the culture. Antibiogram done by a method shown in the image. Name the culture technique used in this method.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Image shown here is Antibiogram – Kirby Bauer method
Lawn culture / Carpet culture – Disk diffusion method

questions.text: All the following structures are present in all the bacteria except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Some bacteria devoid of cell wall. 
Eg. Stable L forms - Mycoplasma

questions.text: An outbreak of postsurgical wound infections caused by S. aureus has occurred in the hospital. The infection control team was asked to determine whether the organism could be carried by one of the operating room personnel. Using your knowledge of normal ﬂora, which one of the following body sites is the most likely location for this organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Staphylococcus aureus usually in habitats in nose (Anterior nares)
Colon – Bacterioides and E. coli
Mouth – Viridans group
Gingival cervices – Actinomyces, Fusobacterium

questions.text: The complement system plays a key role in the host defense process. Which of the following components of this system is the most important in chemotaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

C3a and C5a are potent mediators of inflammation; that is, they have anaphylatoxin activity. 
This activity is characterized by smooth-muscle contraction and the degranulation of mast cells and basophils leading to the release of histamine and other vasoactive substances, causing increased vascular (capillary) permeability. 
C5a is the most potent of these anaphylatoxins; however, it also serves another role as a potent chemotactic agent, attracting polymorphonucleated neutrophils and macrophages to the site of inflammation.

questions.text: Select the correct interpretation of an immunoprecipitation reaction shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It is two dimension double diffusion test (Ouchterlony test)
Here 1 is same as 1 and 1 is not same as 2
Partial identity.

questions.text: Macrophages seen in the organ shown in the image are named as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Littoral cells - Spleen
Hofbauer cells - Placenta
Dust cells - lungs
Microglial cells - Brain

questions.text: A cytokine that converts Th1 subset from Th0 cells is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

IL12 converts TH0 into TH1 cells.

questions.text: Choose the correct pair
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Type I HSR – PK reaction
Type II HSR – DIHA
Type III – Katayama fever
Type IV – GVHD

questions.text: Choose the correct structure shown in the image and the Chromosomal location of β2 Microglobulin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Image shown here is MHC I
It contains alpha 1,2,3 present is short of chromosome 6.
Beta 2 microglobulin present in chromosome 15.

questions.text: The immunological reaction shown in the image is an example for
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

When the antibody instead of antigens is adsorbed on the carrier particle for detection of antigens, it is called reverse passive agglutination.

questions.text: ADCC belongs to which type of hypersensitivity
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Virus infected cells can also be killed by ADCC. In this process, target  cells are killed by a combination of IgG and phagocytic cells. 
The antibody bound to the surface of the infected cells is recognized by IgG receptor on the surface of phagocytic cells (e.g., macrophages, NK cells) and the infected cell is killed. 
After  killing of the virus-infected cells, the cytotoxic T cells are not damaged and can continue to kill other cells infected with the same virus. 
However, the cytotoxic T cells do not have any effect on free virus; they have effect only on virus-infected cells.
Type II hypersensitivity results from misdirected antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC)

choices.text: Vaccination is a method of active immunization
Vaccination is a method of passive immunization
Vaccination is a method of artificial passive immunization
Vaccination is a method of natural passive immunization

questions.text: Find the true statement regarding vaccination
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vaccination – Artificial Active immunization
Infections – Natural Active immunization
Maternal antibodies – Natural passive immunization
Immunoglobulins/serum – artificial passive immunization.

questions.text: Selective medium for a pathogen causing Bull neck appearance of the child as shown in the image is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bull neck caused by C. diphtheriae.
Selective medium is Tinsdale medium.

questions.text: A 8-year-old boy from rural village is brought to the pediatrician by his mother. His mother states that the boy had a deep cut several days ago, which she thoroughly washed and applied mud to prevent oozing. He has now been having severe muscle spasms. On examination, the clinical finding is shown in the image. Choose the best the pathological mechanism behind this boy's presentation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It’s a case of tetanus caused by Clostridium tetani
C. tetani produces at least two distinct toxins—an oxygen-labile hemolysin (tetanolysin) and a powerful plasmid-encoded, heat-labile neurotoxin (tetanospasmin). 
The toxin acts by preventing the release of neurotransmitters, such as gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), glycine, etc., thereby specifically blocking synaptic inhibition in the spinal cord. This leads to unregulated spread of impulses, inhibited anywhere in the central nervous system.

questions.text: A 70 year old women admitted with cough, respiratory distress with purulent expectoration. Sputum Gram smear reveals the pathogen which is shown in the image. Choose the correct test used to demonstrate the virulent factor for this pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The Gram stain revealed Gram positive diplococci in lanceolate shape which is suggestive of S. pneumoniae. 
The main virulent factor is Polysaccharide capsule. 
The capsule is demonstrated by Quellung reaction. 
All other choices are used to diagnose Pneumococci.

questions.text: An18 year old student, with a history of playing in a pond in a rat-infested area, admitted with meningitis and acute renal failure. No PMN cells seen in CSF microscopy. His urine specimen submitted for a direct dark-field examination. Spiral shape organisms are seen in the specimen. Which medium should be inoculated to isolate the suspected organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Suspected case of leptospirosis, the selective medium is Fletcher’s semi solid agar.
Another medium is EMJH medium.

questions.text: All the following Atypical Mycobacteria belongs to Photochromogens EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Photochromogens – M. asiaticum, M. smiae, M. kansasii, and M. marinum
Scotochromogen – M. scrofulaceum, M. gordonae, M. celatum and M. szulgai

questions.text: Gold standard test to diagnose swamp fever is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Swamp fever is otherwise named as leptospirosis.
It is caused by Leptospira interrogans.
Gold standard test is Microscopic agglutination test.
Selective medium – EMJH medium.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female is brought to the causality with high fever and confusion. She complains of chills and myalgias and physical examination reveals a petechial rash. Petechial biopsy reveals a Gram-negative diplococcus. Choose the virulent factor responsible for the petechial rash.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lipo-oligosaccharide (LOS) endotoxin is present in the outer membrane of N. meningitidis. 
It is responsible for damage of the blood vessels associated with meningococcal infections. 
The endotoxin comprises two antigenic determinant components: (a) a protein component and (b) a carbohydrate component. 
The continuous production and release of endotoxin by N. meningitidis cause severe endotoxin reaction, seen in patients with meningococcal disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of sudden onset of fever, headache, chills, and a painful swelling in his left groin. His physical exam is notable for an enlarged lymph node in the inguinal region that is extremely tender to palpation. Microscopic examination of the lymph node aspirates shown in the image revealed the pathogen. Which of the following was the most likely vector that transmitted the disease to this for patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It’s a case of bubonic plague
Microscopy shows typical safety pin appearance bacteria – Yersinia pestis
Vector for Y. pestis is rat flea – Xenopsylla cheopis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female noticed the development of a greenish ear discharge several days after swimming in a public pool. Culture shown in the image A. Choose the false statement regarding the pathogen responsible for her condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Colony morphology and the clinical scenario suggestive of swimmer’s ear caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
It is motile
It is a non-fermenter which utilizes the sugars oxidatively.
Exotoxin A acts against EF2 inhibits protein synthesis.

questions.text: Motility exhibited by the pathogen causing Lyme’s disease is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lyme’s disease caused by Borrelia burgdoferi.
It exhibits lashing motility.
Darting/ Shooting star – Vibrio
Tumbling - Listeria

questions.text: A 42-year-old man came with injury in the face as shown in the image. He was not received any tetanus vaccine in the past 15 years. What may the next management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The wound shown in the image is clean wound.
No H/o TT vaccination with the past 10 years.
As per the current guidelines, the management should be Wound debridement and administration of one dose of Td toxoid.

questions.text: Human lymphocytic ehrlichiosis is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lymphocytic –  Neorickettsia sennetsu
Granulocytic – Anaplasma phagocytophilum
Monocytic – Ehrlichia chafeensis

questions.text: What is the complication of C. jejuni?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

GBS is the complication associated with C. jejuni.
Mainly associated with O19

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to her physician with complaints of vaginal discharge with rotten fish smell, that began about 3 days ago. A sample was obtained, and a wet mount was made of the discharge, shown in the figure below. Choose the correct etiological agent.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Clue cells are the diagnostic of Bacterial vaginosis
Caused by Gardnerella vaginalis

questions.text: The lesion shown in the picture is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sinus, swelling and discharging Sulphur granules 
Cervicofacial actinomycosis
Caused by A. israelii

questions.text: Sudoku fever is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sudoku fever caused by Spirillum minus.
Motile bacteria exhibits darting motility.
It causes carditis and rat bite fever.

questions.text: After 12 days in the intensive care unit following an automobile accident, an 18-year-old college student develops increased urinary urgency, burning micturition and lower abdominal pain. His urine culture plate shown in the image which revealed the probable pathogen. What is the most likely organism causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Serratia is a gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic bacillus.
Serratia is a common cause of nosocomial urinary tract infections, along with E. coli, Proteus, Klebsiella and Pseudomonas. 
Some strains produce a red pigment.
Nosocomial infections generally are more resistant than community acquired infections.

questions.text: Most sensitive test used in the diagnosis of H. pylori is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Most sensitive, accurate, quick and simple
Used for prognosis - monitoring of treatment (becomes negative after improvement) 
Culture is most specific but may be insensitive because of difficulty with H. pylori isolation

questions.text: Selective medium for the bacteria causing Andaman fever is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Swamp fever / Andaman fever caused by Leptospira interrogans
Selective media for leptospira are EMJH medium, Korthof medium and Fletcher medium

questions.text: School of fish arrangement is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Haemophilus ducreyi is a fastidious gram-negative coccobacillus bacteria, which causes the sexually transmitted disease chancroid, a major cause of genital ulceration in developing countries characterized by painful sores on the genitalia. 
H. ducreyi gram stain appears as "school of fish” or tram track appearance

questions.text: Erythema arthriticum caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Rat-bite fever is usually caused by the bite of a rat or occasionally by the bite of a mouse, cat, squirrel, or dog. 
The disease also occurs without rat bite and is believed to occur due to ingestion of raw meat or water contaminated by excreta of the rat. 
This condition is known as Haverhill’s fever or erythema arthriticum epidemicum.

questions.text: Reiter’s syndrome due to Chlamydia trachomatis is associated with all the following features except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reiter’s syndrome is a triad of recurrent conjunctivitis,  polyarthritis, and urethritis or cervicitis, and is most commonly associated with genital infection caused by C. trachomatis. 
This condition is seen in both men and women. Approximately, 50–60% of patients with Reiter’s syndrome have a genital infection with C. trachomatis at onset of arthritis. 
EBs have been demonstrated in synovial fluid of patients suffering from arthritis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was bitten by a stray dog as the bite wounds shown in the image. He has previous history of rabies vaccination six months before. Choose the appropriate Management.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Image shown here is category III bite
It needs rabies vaccine with Rig
Already vaccinated individuals needed 0 and 3 doses rabies vaccine only.

questions.text: Lip Shultz bodies are seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Yellow fever virus – Torres bodies
Herpes virus – Lipshultz bodies
Adeno virus – Cowdry B bodies
Polio virus - Cowdry B bodies

questions.text: All the following viruses are possessing helical symmetry except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Viruses possessing helical symmetry are
Corona virirus
Myxo viruses
Bunya virus
Filo virus
Rhabdo virus

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman Is found to have chronic viral hepatitis B on liver biopsy. The presence of which of the following serologic markers is most likely to increase the risk of vertical transmission of the virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Presence HBeAg indicates  high infectivity.
HBcAg is not a serological marker
Anti HBcAg IgG – Chronic or Past infection

questions.text: Based on the ecology shown in the image, identify the correct virus.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CCHF 
Vector is Tick

questions.text: A 30-year-old commercial sex worker was tested for HIV in an ICTC. The results shown in the image. Choose the correct interpretation based on current NACO guideline.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A1+ A2- A3- in high-risk group people is inderminate
A1+ A2- A3- in low-risk group people is Negative

choices.text: IgG persists for more than 6 months
IgM antibody is present at birth
Most common anomalies are hearing and heart defects
Increased congenital malformation if infection after 16 weeks

questions.text: All the following statement are true regarding Congenital rubella syndrome except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Congenital malformations are commonest during the first trimester and if infection occurs very early in pregnancy fetusmay die. 
85% fetal damage occurs in first trimester.

questions.text: Seronegative infectious mononucleosis is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Seronegative infectious mononucleosis is caused by CMV. 
Paul Bunnnel test is negative

questions.text: Choose the surface protein which is commonly seen in all the Paramyxoviruses
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fusion protein seen in all the paramyxoviruses including Mumps, Measles, RSV and Para influenza virus
Glycoproteins of some enveloped viruses (paramyxoviruses, herpesviruses, and retroviruses) are expressed on host cell surface which triggers the fusion of neighbouring cell so form multi nucleated giant cells called syncytia, that allows die virus to spread from cell to cell and escapes antibody neutralization.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is suffering from fatigue and jaundice. His laboratory workup is positive for HBsAg, positive for IgM antibody to HBcAg, positive for HBeAb, and negative for HBsAb, Which of the following is the most likely definition of his status?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Since the patient is symptomatic, positive for HBsAg and IgM against HBcAg, he is probably in the acute stage of infection. 
He has developed antibodies against the HBeAg so he is not highly contagious.

questions.text: Which adenovirus types are frequent causes of acute respiratory disease among military recruits?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Adenovirus serotype 3,4,and 7 causes pharyngo conjunctival fever among military recruits.
8,19 ,37 causes epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.
40,41 causes infantile diarrhea.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman admitted with several episodes of bloody diarrhea. She is HIV antibody positive with a CD4 count of 50. Stool cultures for Shigella, Salmonella, and Campylobacter were negative. An assay for Clostridium difficile toxin was negative. Colonoscopy revealed many ulcerated lesions. Biopsy shown in the image. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Image shown here is owl eye inclusions suggestive of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) / HHV5.
It causes bloody diarrhoea and interstitial pneumonia.
Transplant transmitted infections among renal transplant recipients.
Treatment – Ganciclovir, Valganciclovir.

questions.text: In Japanese Encephalitis, pigs acts as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Japanese encephalitis:• Reservoir host: Ardeid (wading) birds: Herons, cattle ergets, ducks• Amplifying hosts: Pigs (asymptomatic), bats• Mosquito attractant: Cattle and Buffalo (infected but not natural host of JE)• Incidental hosts: Horses (only animal to be symptomatic), humans(dead end), others. 
Vector – Culex mosquito

questions.text: Plasmodium having exoerythrocytic cycle causes relapse. Relapse is due to hypnozoites. Hypnozoites are seen in which of the following plasmodium species
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypnozoites stage seen in P. vivax and P. ovale
They cause relapse.

questions.text: Name the arrow marked structure in the lifecycle of intestinal fluke
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Intestinal fluke is F. buski
Arrow marked structure is miracidium – first stage larva

questions.text: Identify the nematode based on the microfilaria as shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sheathed and nuclei extended to tail tip suggestive of Loa loa

questions.text: Choose the right pair
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Black fly – O. volvulus – Sowdah
Tsetse fly – T. brucei – African sleeping sickness / Winterbottom sign
Sandfly – Leishmania – kalaazar
Deerfly – Loa loa – Calabar swelling

questions.text: Choose the diagnostic stage of a nematode which causes Cutaneous larva migrans.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cutaneous larva migrans caused by Ancylostoma brasiliensis.
Hook worm – Egg is the diagnostic stage
Clear shell with 4-8 blastomere suggestive of Hookworm egg.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female working at a zoo as a primate intern developed gastrointestinal symptoms including diarrhea and cramping. She sought medical attention from her health care provider which included a stool examination for ova and parasites (O & P). Stool wet mount preparation shown in the image. What will be the accidental host for this pathogen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Image shown here is trophozoite of Balantidium coli – Ciliate protozoa.
Natural host: Pig. 
Accidental host: Man.
Reservoirs: Pig, monkey, and rat.
Infective form: Cyst.

questions.text: Which vector is associated with disease caused by Onchocerca volvulus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The Simulium black fly is the vector of 0. volvulus infections (onchocerciasis). 
The black fly becomes infected when it bites the skin of a person with onchocerciasis. 
The fly ingests the microfilaria in the skin of the infected individual, and then the microfilaria (or embryo ) penetrates through the stomach wall of this fly and localizes in the thoracic muscles, where it mature to a first stage larva. 
The larva then migrates to the head and proboscis and matures to the second- and then third-stage larval forms. 
During this third stage, the larva is infectious and when transmitted to a new human host during a bite, establishes disease in humans.
Onchocerca larvae mature to adults in the subcutaneous tissues of humans and produce microfilariae that migrate in the skin.

questions.text: Disease caused by which parasite is associated with consumption of contaminated fish?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

D. latum, the fish tapeworm, has a complex life cycle involving freshwater crustacean and fish as Intermediate hosts and humans as the primary host. 
Ingestion of inadequately cooked fish exposes the human host to the larval worm plerocercoid larvae. 
It causes megaloblastic anaemia

questions.text: All the following causes auto infection except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Autoinfection caused by H. nana, T. solium, E. vermicularis, C. parvum and S. stercoralis.

questions.text: A child admitted with the complaints of diarrhoea. Stool examination revealed the pathogen as shown in the image.Choose the complication lead by this pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Image shown here depicts Trichuris trichiura egg.
Complication in children – rectal prolapse
In adults – Iron deficiency anaemia.

questions.text: Rhabditiform larva is diagnostic stage in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Rhabditiform larva is diagnostic stage of Strongyloides stercoralis.
Human excretes rhabditiform larva in stool.
It causes autoinfection and hyper infection syndrome.
Treatment – Ivermectin.

questions.text: Second intermediate host for Clonorchis sinensis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fish is the second intermediate host for Clonorchis sinensis.
Crab – P. westermanii
Plant – F. buski and F. hepatica

questions.text: A 27-year-old PLHIV admitted with progressively increasing dyspnea over the past 3 weeks. He also complains of a dry, painful cough, fatigue, and low-grade fever. A chest x-ray reveals bilateral symmetrical interstitial and alveolar infiltration. Which of the following agents is the most likely cause of the above?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The clues are AIDS patient and atypical pneumonia. Pneumocystis jirovecii is the hallmark atypical pneumonia of AIDS.
Pneumocystis is classified under fungus based on nucleic acid sequence studies:
It exist in two forms - In environment cysts are found, whereas in human tissues both cysts and trophozoites are found.
Cysts are inhaled, carried to the lungs, transformed into trophozoite stage which induces an inflammatory response that leads to recruitment of plasma cells resulting in formation of frothy exudate filling the alveoli – Honey comb appearance.

questions.text: A chronic debilitated patient on intravenous nutrients and high-lipid fluids has developed septicemia that cultures out on blood agar only when overlaid with sterile olive oil. The LPCB mount of culture shown in the image. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Spaghetti meat ball appearance in microscopy suggestive of Malassezia
Lipophilic nature suggestive of Malassezia furfur.
M. pachydermatidis is non lipophilic

questions.text: A 46 year old farmer presents with multiple discharging sinuses in the leg as shown in the image started with antibiotics. HPE examination revealed the diagnosis. Lesions are not responding to antibiotics. The most likely etiological agent may be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mycetoma is a slowly progressive, chronic granulomatous infection of skin and subcutaneous tissues with occasional involvement of underlying fascia and bone usually affecting extremities. 
The condition is characterized by a triad of tumefaction,  draining sinuses, and  granules.
During the course of infection, microabscesses burst open with the formation of chronic multiple sinuses discharging copious, seropurulent fluid containing granules. 
The color and consistency of these granules vary depending on the fungi that cause the disease 
Mycotic mycetoma require surgical treatment by amputation, while actinomycotic mycetoma are treated well by antibiotics.

questions.text: Patient came with tinea unguium. LPCB mount of a fungal pathogen grown in the SDA agar shown in the image. Identify the pathogen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Club shape macroconidia and absence of microconidia suggestive of Epidermophyton.
Nail infection caused by trichophyton and Epidermophyton.
Pencil shaped macroconidia with abundant microconidia suggestive of trichophyton.

questions.text: All the following are causing endemic mycosis except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Endemic or systemic mycosis caused by Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides, Histoplasma and Blastomyces.
They confined to a particular geographical area, so named as endemic mycosis.

questions.text: All the following are dimorphic fungi except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Thermally dimorphic fungi exists in two forms. Based on the temperature, they change their morphology.
At 37 deg, in tissues – Yeast form and at 25 deg in environment – Mold form.
Sporothrix, Talaromyces and all systemic mycosis are examples for dimorphic fungi.

questions.text: Most common fungal infection seen in febrile neutropenia is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Febrile neutropenia- Fever more than 38.5°C and absolute neutrophil count less than 500/µl.
Neutrophils/CMI play crucial role in controlling Candida infection, hence deep seated and disseminated Candidainfections are common in Neutropenic patients

questions.text: Specific stain used to demonstrate Cryptococcus neoformans is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cryptococcus neoformans is carminiphilic fungi.
Specific stain used to demonstrate Cryptococcus is mucicarmine stain.
India ink and nigrosin stain are negative stains used to demonstrate the capsule

questions.text: Copper penny bodies seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Wart like lesions and HPE shows Copper penny / sclerotic bodies suggestive of Chromoblastomycosis.
Sub cutaneous fungal infections.
Caused by Phialophora, Cladospora and Fonsecaea.
